Od treh ton zlata je ostala zgolj voda
Iz rudarsko-metalurškega velikana v Boru naj bi med letoma 2010 in 2018 izginilo zlato, vredno približno 120 milijonov evrov, ugotavljajo kitajski lastniki.
05 Nov 2019, 12:02 by Veso Stojanov



REUTERSTopljenje bakrove rude v topilnici bakra v Boru (levo)



REUTERSPridobivanje zlata iz anodnega mulja



REUTERSRudarji v rudniku bakra v Boru FOTOGRAFIJE: REUTERS



REUTERSOdprti kop rudnika bakra Krivelj pri Boru



REUTERSVlivanje čistega zlata v kalupe


V Srbiji še vedno poteka preiskava »ropa stoletja«, odkar so letos spomladi ugotovili, da je iz rudarskega giganta RTB Bor, ki je od lani v večinski lasti kitajske rudarske družbe Zijin, med letoma 2010 in 2017 izginilo več kot tri tone zlata, vrednega najmanj 120 milijonov evrov. Kot je mogoče prebrati v nekaterih srbskih medijih, zlasti v Večernjih novostih, za zdaj preiskovalci še vedno niso ugotovili natančne količine zlata, ki je izginilo neznano kam.Zlato za hotelEden od priprtih osumljencev za krajo zlata v Boru je lani kupil delež v hotelu, ki so ga gradili v znanem srbskem zimskem središču Kopaonik. Osumljeni, čigar ime javnosti še ni znano, je spraševal investitorja hotela, ali lahko vloži nekaj denarja v gradnjo hotela. Investitor je sprva mislil, da gre za šalo, in odvrnil, da lahko, ampak da ga bo delež stal tri milijone evrov. Že naslednji dan je na račun investitorja nakazal tri milijone evrov.Dokler niso vajeti v RTB Bor, kamor spadajo ne samo rudniki bakra v Boru, temveč tudi v Majdanpeku in vsi obrati za predelavo izkopanih rudnin, prevzeli novi lastniki iz Kitajske, so v Zlatarni, kot so popularno imenovali obrat za pridelavo zlata in drugih plemenitih kovin iz anodnega blata oziroma mulja, le enkrat do dvakrat na tri do štiri mesece zagnali stroje za pridelavo zlata. Ker se je ves proces odvijal bolj sporadično in brez kakšnega večjega nadzora, je pri izginotju zlata, kot zdaj ugotavljajo preiskovalci, lahko sodelovalo večje število ljudi.
Kitajski nadzor


Pridobivanje zlata iz anodnega muljaREUTERS

Ko je decembra lani 63-odstotno lastništvo nad Rudarsko-topilniškim bazenom Bor dobil novi lastnik iz Kitajske, so procese pridobivanja zlata iz anodnega mulja začeli izvajati redno vsak teden, poleg tega so Kitajci izjemno poostrili disciplino in nadzor. Prav to zdaj bega preiskovalce, kajti pred prihodom Kitajcev je vrsto let veljalo, da so proces pridelave zlata opravljali bolj sporadično, domnevno zato, da naj bi se nabralo dovolj anodnega mulja in bi bil zato ves postopek pridobivanja zlata bolj ekonomičen. A kot kaže, je bila ta sporadičnost bolj izgovor, da so se lahko večje količine zlata znašle v žepih nekaterih zaposlenih.Preiskovalci so se za zdaj osredotočili na obdobje od začetka leta 2014 do 1. aprila 2017, ko naj bi po izsledkih analize, ki so jo naredili na Inštitutu za kemijsko tehnologijo in metalurgijo Univerze v Beogradu, izginilo skoraj 900 kilogramov zlata, vrednega okrog 33 milijonov evrov. A kot je za Večernje novosti povedal poznavalec razmer, ki sodeluje v preiskavi, a je hotel ostati anonimen, so se v Boru sledi za zlatom začele zgubljati že leta 2010 in na podlagi nekaterih indicev so zdaj sestavili približno oceno, da je od takrat do leta 2018 izginilo tri tone zlata v vrednosti 120 milijonov evrov.
900 kg zlata je iz Bora izginilo med letom 2014 in 1. aprilom 2017.
Anodni mulj


Odprti kop rudnika bakra Krivelj pri BoruREUTERS

Zlato, srebro, platino, tudi druge redke kovine, kot so selen in telur, v Boru pridobivajo iz anodnega mulja. Gre za stranski produkt, ki ostane po procesu pridobivanja elektrolize bakra iz bakrove rude. Ta črna kaša ostane na dnu elektrolizne banje in je dobesedno zlata vredna, saj se v njej naberejo vse vredne in redke kovine. Preden iz tega anodnega mulja nastanejo zlate palice, je potreben določen proces. Najprej mulj po tekočem traku prepeljejo v obrat, kjer ga obdelajo z močno žvepleno kislino in zapečejo, da odstranijo nestabilne snovi, nato pa gre kaša v topljenje. Rezultat je srebrno-zlata zlitina oziroma zlitina doré (doré v francoščini pomeni zlat oziroma pozlačen). S kemijskimi reakcijami to zlitino nato ločijo: zlato se izloči skupaj z malo primesmi, iz česar pozneje pridobijo čisti zlati prah. Srebro ostane v raztopini. Tega očistijo in pošljejo naprej na elektrolizo, med katero pridobijo čiste srebrove kristale, ločevanje pa poteka na podlagi njihovih različnih reaktivnosti in topnosti. Tako z različnimi pristopi iz anodnega mulja pridobijo še veliko dragocenih kovin.Če v Boru, kot zdaj ugotavljajo, niso vodili natančne evidence, koliko anodnega mulja je nastalo pri elektrolizi bakrene rude, ni čudno, da je nekaj tega zlatega mulja zmanjkalo. Poleg tega so srbski mediji zdaj odkrili, da je v okolici Bora obstajalo več ilegalnih topilnic zlata, v katerih so predelovali anodni mulj, ki so ga posamezniki kar v vrečah nosili s tovarniških dvorišč.Proti fizikalnim zakonomNihče ne ve, kako je mogoče, da sta v dokumentaciji obrata Zlatarna količina in teža čistega zlata, ki so jo dobili po koncu procesa rafinacije, močno presegli količino anodnega mulja oziroma zlitine doré, kar je po vseh fizikalnih in kemijskih zakonih nemogoče. Razlog za to je, domnevajo preiskovalci, v zelo slabo vodenih knjigah in nespoštovanju običajnih proizvodnih procedur.
Nihče ničesar ne ve


Vlivanje čistega zlata v kalupeREUTERS

Preiskovalci so doslej zaslišali že več kot 50 ljudi, a kot ugotavljajo nekateri srbski mediji, jim ti na pogovorih niso kaj posebno pomagali. Na vprašanje, kako je mogoče, da konec leta, ko so delali bilance, niso opazili, da manjka toliko zlata, so vsi odgovorili z enostavnim odgovorom: Ne vemo. Doslej so aretirali štiri delavce iz Zlatarne, dva nekdanja delavca z istega obrata in še enega varnostnika. Sodišče je vsem sedmim odvzelo kar 48 nepremičnin (hiš in vikendov), ki so jih imeli v lasti, pri pregledu stanovanj pa so našli nekaj več kot 136.000 evrov, skoraj 4000 dolarjev, skoraj 100.000 srbskih dinarjev in več kot kilogram zlata. Sedmerica je že od začetka maja v priporu, kjer čakajo na sojenje, policisti pa so nekaterim srbskim novinarjem povedali, da bo na koncu preiskave seznam osumljenih za krajo stoletja morda bistveno daljši.Prav tako so se preiskovalci spraševali, kako je mogoče, da je bilo v vodi, ki jo uporabljajo pri izpiranju zlitine, več zlata kot na začetku procesa. Vse to je mogoče, pravijo strokovnjaki, ki se spoznajo na proces pridobivanja zlata iz anodnega mulja, ker se je vse skupaj delalo zelo sporadično in verjetno prav zaradi možnosti odtujevanja zlata iz topilnice, dokumentacija ni bila vodena posebno natančno. Praviloma sta bili vpisani samo teža in količina vhodnega materiala – anodnega mulja –, preostale parametre dela, ki se uporabljajo pri nadaljnji rafinaciji zlata, kot so trajanje postopka, količin kisline, ki so jo uporabljali, količina vode in kakšna je bila temperatura, pa so v dokumentacijo vnašali bolj po domače. Pogosto so bili ti parametri napisani na roko, zato so včasih nečitljivi, kar preiskovalcem še dodatno otežuje delo.
Srbski rudarsko-metalurški gigant RTB Bor je od lani v večinski lasti kitajske rudarske družbe Zijin.
Prelaganje odgovornosti
Ko je srbski posebni oddelek državnega tožilstva za organizirani kriminal ugotovil, da je količina ukradenega zlata bistveno večja, kot so sprva sumili, so nekdanji vodilni ljudje RTB Bor začeli s prstom kazati na Inštitut za rudarstvo in metalurgijo (IRM) v Boru, ki naj bi spremljalo ves proces pridobivanja zlata v Boru. Kot dokaz so preiskovalcem tožilstva dostavili neki dokument, ki naj bi dokazoval nevestno delo v IRM, a se je potem izkazalo, da je ta sporni dokument celo ponarejen. Vodstvo RTB Bora naj bi se sklicevalo na mnenje, ki naj bi ga o nevestnem početju IRM izdelali trije strokovnjaki beograjskega Inštituta za tehnologijo jedrskih in drugih mineralnih snovi.Pozneje se je izkazalo, da dva od treh strokovnjakov o omenjenem »lastnem mnenju« sploh nista imela pojma, tretja strokovnjakinja, ki naj bi pri tem sodelovala, pa je bila že več kot leto dni v pokoju in nikakor se ne bi mogla podpisati pod mnenje svojega nekdanjega delodajalca. Nekdanji vodilni rudarsko-metalurškega kompleksa v Boru zdaj pravijo, da zadeve ne morejo komentirati, ker preiskava še poteka, a prav vsi, s katerimi so se pogovarjali srbski novinarji, nekako ne morejo verjeti, da bi bila sploh možna kraja zlata takšnih razsežnosti.

Of the three tons of gold, only water remained
Gold miners worth about 120 million euros are expected to disappear from the Bor-mining giant in Bor between 2010 and 2018, according to Chinese owners.
05 Nov 2019, 12:02 by Veso Stojanov



REUTERMining of copper ore in a copper smelter in Bor (left)



REUTERSRecovering gold from anode sludge



REUTERSRuders at Bor Coal Mine PHOTOS: REUTERS



REUTERSOne open pit of the Krivelj copper mine in Bor



REUTERS Pouring pure gold into molds


Serbia is still investigating a "robbery of the century" since more than three tonnes of gold worth by the Chinese mining company Zijin disappeared from the mining giant RTB Bor, which last year was last year, this spring. at least € 120 million. As can be read in some Serbian media, especially in Vecernje Novosti, investigators have not yet determined the exact amount of gold that has disappeared unknown.Gold for HotelOne of the suspected Bor steal suspects last year bought a stake in a hotel that it was built in the famous Serbian winter resort Kopaonik. The suspect, whose name is not yet known, asked the hotel investor if he could invest some money in building the hotel. The investor initially thought it was a joke and said he could, but that the stake would cost him three million euros. The next day, he had deposited three million euros at the expense of the investor. Until they are included in RTB Bor, which includes not only the copper mines in Bor, but also in Majdanpek and all the plants for the extraction of minerals have been taken over by the new owners in China, as they used to call the gold and other precious metals anode sludge and sludge plant, only once or twice every three to four months did they start the gold-mining machinery. As the whole process took place more sporadically and without any greater scrutiny, more people could participate in the disappearance of gold, as investigators now find.
Chinese control


Extraction of gold from anode sludgeREUTERS

When a new owner from China acquired 63% ownership of the Bor Mining and Smelter Basin last December, the anode sludge gold mining process began on a regular basis every week, with the Chinese tightening discipline and control. This is precisely what escapes investigators, because before the arrival of the Chinese, it was believed for many years that the gold production process was carried out more sporadically, presumably in order to accumulate enough anode sludge and thus make the entire gold production process more economical. But this sporadicness seems to have been more of an excuse that more gold may have been in the pockets of some employees.The investigators have for now focused on the period from early 2014 to April 1, 2017, according to the analysis that it was made at the Institute of Chemical Technology and Metallurgy, University of Belgrade, and nearly 900 kilograms of gold worth about 33 million euros disappeared. However, as a connoisseur of the situation involved in the investigation, but wanted to remain anonymous, told the Vecernje Novosti newspaper, the traces of gold in Bor had already begun to decline in 2010 and, based on some indications, have now estimated that from then to In 2018, three tonnes of gold worth EUR 120 million disappeared.
900 kg of gold disappeared from Bor between 2014 and April 1, 2017.
Anode sludge


Open pit of the Krivelj copper mine at BoruREUTERS

Gold, silver, platinum and other rare metals, such as selenium and tellurium, are extracted from anode sludge in Bor. It is a by-product that remains after the process of obtaining copper electrolysis from copper ore. This black porridge stays at the bottom of the electrolysis bath and is literally gold worth, as all the valuable and rare metals are accumulated in it. A certain process is required before gold bars are formed from this anode sludge. First, the sludge is transported through a conveyor belt to a plant where it is treated with strong sulfuric acid and baked to remove unstable substances, and then the slurry goes into melting. The result is a silver-gold alloy or doré alloy (doré in French means gold or gilded). By chemical reactions, this alloy is then separated: the gold is extracted with little admixture, from which pure gold powder is subsequently obtained. Silver remains in solution. This is purified and forwarded to electrolysis, during which pure silver crystals are obtained, and the separation is carried out on the basis of their different reactivity and solubility. Thus, with different approaches from anode sludge, many more precious metals are obtained. If, as they now state, they did not keep a precise record of how much anode sludge was generated by copper ore electrolysis, it is no wonder that some of this gold sludge has run out. In addition, Serbian media has now discovered that there were several illegal gold smelters in the Bor area surrounding the processing of anode sludge, which were used by individuals to carry them from factory yards. According to physical laws, no one knows how it is possible in the documentation of the plant, the amount of gold and the amount of pure gold obtained after the refining process were exceeded exceeded the amount of anode sludge or doré alloys, which is impossible under all physical and chemical laws. The reason for this is, the investigators suspect, in very poorly kept books and disregard for normal production procedures.
Nobody knows anything


Pouring Pure Gold into MoldsREUTERS

Investigators have heard more than 50 people so far, but as some Serbian media have noted, they have not helped them much in the talks. When asked how it was possible that at the end of the year when they were doing the balance sheets they did not notice that there was so much gold missing, they all answered with a simple answer: We do not know. So far, four jewelry workers have been arrested, two former workers from the same plant and another security guard. The court confiscated as many as 48 properties (houses and cottages) they owned, and found just over $ 136,000, nearly $ 4,000, nearly 100,000 Serbian dinars and more than a kilo of gold in a home inspection. The seven have been in custody pending trial since early May, and police have told some Serbian journalists that the list of suspected thefters of the century may be significantly longer at the end of the investigation. Investigators have also wondered how it was possible there is more gold in the water used to flush the alloy than at the beginning of the process. All this is possible, say experts familiar with the process of extracting gold from anode sludge, because everything was done very sporadically, and probably because of the possibility of disposing of gold from the smelter, the documentation was not kept particularly accurate. As a rule, only the weight and quantity of the input material - the anode sludge - were entered, and the remaining parameters of the work used to further refine the gold, such as the duration of the process, the amounts of acid used, the amount of water and what the temperature was more typed into the documentation. Often, these parameters are handwritten, so they are sometimes illegible, making it even more difficult for investigators to work with.
Serbia's mining and metallurgical giant RTB Bor is a majority-owned subsidiary of Chinese mining company Zijin since last year.
Shifting responsibility
When the Serbian Special Department of the Prosecutor's Office for Organized Crime found that the amount of stolen gold was significantly higher than initially suspected, former RTB Bor executives began pointing their finger at the Bor Mining and Metallurgy Institute (IRM) in Ljubljana. monitored the entire process of obtaining gold in Bor. Prosecution investigators were provided with some evidence to prove that they were engaged in IRM work, but then it turned out that this controversial document was even forged. The management of RTB Bora is referring to the opinion that three experts from the Belgrade Institute of Technology of Nuclear and Other Minerals have drawn up about the bribery of IRM. Later on, it turned out that two out of three experts did not even have a "own opinion" The third expert who was supposed to be involved has been in retirement for more than a year and could not in any way sign the opinion of her former employer. Former executives of the Bor mining and metallurgical complex now say they cannot comment on the matter because the investigation is ongoing, but not everyone interviewed by Serbian journalists somehow believes that gold of this magnitude would be possible at all.
